[{'type': 'insert', 'to': 'ii', 'str': 'ii inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

In this context, unstressed vowels, including u, tend to be elided when they occur before nasals, liquids, and semivowels. [{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ā', 'to': 'ā̊', 'str': 'ā̊ for ā', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'This is a well-documented orthographic feature in Iranian manuscripts, reflecting a tendency for the letter ā̊ to disappear by evolving into ā. This change is particularly prevalent in later Iranian copies from the 19th century, where ā replaces ā̊ in a high percentage of occurrences (over 75% in some manuscripts). [{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ōi', 'to': 'aō', 'str': 'aō for ōi', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "This feature represents a confusion within a broader group of spellings including aō, ōi, aōi, and ō. [{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ai', 'to': 'ii', 'str': 'ii for ai', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'The sources discuss ii primarily in relation to ī (and y/ẏ), where uu for ū and ii for ī are described as a scriptural convention in Indian manuscripts influenced by Gujarati orthography, with inverse spellings also occurring'}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'i', 'str': 'i inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). [{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'i', 'str': 'i for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Iranian manuscripts, the confusion of 'a' for 'i' occurs, especially before nasals or after 'r' (e.g., 'tną' for 'tą', 'ϑrətiia-' for 'ϑritiia-'). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. [{'type': 'insert', 'to': 'i', 'str': 'i inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'insert', 'to': 'a', 'str': 'a inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]
